sn7.13:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā vātehābādhiko hoti;
sn7.13:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was afflicted by winds.
sn7.13:1.2.comm: Vātehābādhika is a syntactic compound, “afflicted by winds” (vātehi). It is one of the illnesses noted at AN 10.60:7.4. In Ayurveda, diseases of the winds may have many causes, chief among them faulty digestion.

sn7.13:1.3.pli: āyasmā ca upavāṇo bhagavato upaṭṭhāko hoti.
sn7.13:1.3.comm: In DN 16:5.4.5 Upavāna was said to have been the Buddha’s carer for a long time. At DN 29:41.1 he is fanning the Buddha. At AN 5.166, Ānanda goes to Upavāṇa for support when he feels he has disappointed the Buddha. The events of this discourse are recalled by him in his verses at Thag 2.33.

sn7.13:1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ āmantesi:
sn7.13:1.4.eng: Then the Buddha said to Upavāṇa,

sn7.13:1.5.eng: “Please, Upavāṇa, find some hot water for me.”
sn7.13:1.5.comm: Typically ghee or other oil is recommended rather than hot water.

sn7.13:1.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavato paṭissutvā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena devahitassa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tuṇhībhūto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn7.13:1.6.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Upavāṇa. He robed up, and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the brahmin Devahita, and stood silently to one side.

sn7.13:1.7.pli: Addasā kho devahito brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ.

sn7.13:2.2.eng: shaven, wrapped in his outer robe.

sn7.13:2.3.eng: What do you want? What are you looking for?

sn7.13:2.4.eng: What have you come here to ask for?”

sn7.13:3.1.eng: “The perfected one, the Holy One in the world,

sn7.13:3.2.eng: the sage is afflicted by winds.

sn7.13:3.4.eng: give it to the sage, brahmin.

sn7.13:4.1.eng: I wish to bring it to the one

sn7.13:4.2.eng: who is esteemed by the estimable,

sn7.13:5.1.pli: Atha kho devahito brāhmaṇo uṇhodakassa kājaṃ purisena gāhāpetvā phāṇitassa ca puṭaṃ āyasmato upavāṇassa pādāsi.
sn7.13:5.1.eng: Then Devahita had a man fetch a carrying-pole with hot water. He also presented Upavāṇa with a jar of molasses.

sn7.13:5.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ uṇhodakena nhāpetvā uṇhodakena phāṇitaṃ āloletvā bhagavato pādāsi.
sn7.13:5.2.eng: Then Venerable Upavāṇa went up to the Buddha and bathed him with the hot water. Then he stirred molasses into hot water and presented it to the Buddha.

sn7.13:5.3.eng: Then the Buddha’s illness died down.

sn7.13:6.1.pli: Atha kho devahito brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.13:6.1.eng: Then the brahmin Devahita went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.13:6.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
sn7.13:6.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,

sn7.13:6.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho devahito brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.13:6.3.eng: and addressed the Buddha in verse:

sn7.13:7.1.eng: “Where should you give an available gift?

sn7.13:7.2.eng: Where is a gift very fruitful?

sn7.13:7.3.eng: How does one who is donating

sn7.13:7.4.eng: ensure the success of their religious donation?”

sn7.13:8.2.eng: sees heaven and places of loss,

sn7.13:8.3.eng: and has attained the ending of rebirth,

sn7.13:8.4.eng: is a sage of perfect insight.

sn7.13:9.1.eng: Here you should give an available gift;

sn7.13:9.2.eng: what’s given here is very fruitful.

sn7.13:9.3.eng: That’s how a sponsor of sacrifices

sn7.13:9.4.eng: ensures the success of their religious donation.”

sn7.13:10.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, devahito brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.13:10.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Devahita said to the Buddha,

sn7.13:10.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.13:10.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.14:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇamahāsālo lūkho lūkhapāvuraṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.14:1.2.eng: Then a certain well-to-do brahmin, shabby, wearing a shabby cloak, went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.14:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ brāhmaṇamahāsālaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
sn7.14:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

sn7.14:1.4.eng: “Brahmin, why are you so shabby, wearing a shabby cloak?”

sn7.14:1.6.pli: Te maṃ dārehi sampuccha gharā nikkhāmentī”ti.
sn7.14:1.6.eng: At their wives’ bidding they expelled me from my house.”

sn7.14:1.7.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imā gāthāyo pariyāpuṇitvā sabhāyaṃ mahājanakāye sannipatite puttesu ca sannisinnesu bhāsassu:
sn7.14:1.7.eng: “Well then, brahmin, memorize these verses and recite them to your sons when you are all seated in the council hall with a large crowd.

sn7.14:2.1.eng: ‘I was overjoyed when they were born,

sn7.14:2.2.comm: For bhava as “prosperity” see also Dhp 282:4.

sn7.14:2.3.eng: But at their wives’ bidding they chased me out,

sn7.14:3.1.eng: It turns out they’re wicked, those nasty men,

sn7.14:3.2.eng: though they called me their dear old Dad.

sn7.14:3.3.eng: They’re monsters in the shape of sons,

sn7.14:3.4.eng: throwing me out as I’ve grown old.

sn7.14:4.3.eng: the elderly father of those kids

sn7.14:4.4.eng: begs for alms at others’ homes.

sn7.14:5.3.eng: for it wards off a wild bull,

sn7.14:6.1.eng: It goes before me in the dark;

sn7.14:6.2.eng: in deep waters it finds a footing.

sn7.14:6.3.eng: By the wonderful power of this staff,

sn7.14:6.4.eng: when I stumble, I stand firm again.’”

sn7.14:7.1.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇamahāsālo bhagavato santike imā gāthāyo pariyāpuṇitvā sabhāyaṃ mahājanakāye sannipatite puttesu ca sannisinnesu abhāsi:
sn7.14:7.1.eng: Having memorized those verses in the Buddha’s presence, the brahmin recited them to his sons when they were all seated in the council hall with a large crowd. …

sn7.14:13.1.pli: Atha kho naṃ brāhmaṇamahāsālaṃ puttā gharaṃ netvā nhāpetvā paccekaṃ dussayugena acchādesuṃ.
sn7.14:13.1.eng: Then the brahmin’s sons led him back home, bathed him, and each clothed him with a fine pair of garments.

sn7.14:13.2.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇamahāsālo ekaṃ dussayugaṃ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.14:13.2.eng: Then the brahmin, taking one pair of garments, went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.14:13.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho brāhmaṇamahāsālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.14:13.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn7.14:13.4.pli: “mayaṃ, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā nāma ācariyassa ācariyadhanaṃ pariyesāma.
sn7.14:13.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, we brahmins seek a fee for our tutor.

sn7.14:13.5.eng: May the worthy Gotama please accept my tutor’s fee!”
sn7.14:13.5.comm: Note the difference: the brahmins actively seek a payment for teaching, whereas the Buddha receives only what is freely offered.

sn7.14:13.6.eng: So the Buddha accepted it out of sympathy.

sn7.14:13.7.pli: Atha kho so brāhmaṇamahāsālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.14:13.7.eng: Then the well-to-do brahmin said to the Buddha,

sn7.14:13.9.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.14:13.9.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.15:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena mānatthaddho nāma brāhmaṇo sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati.
sn7.15:1.2.eng: Now at that time a brahmin named Stuck-Up was residing in Sāvatthī.
sn7.15:1.2.comm: Mānatthaddha, literally “stiff with pride”. So stiff, apparently, he could not bow. Also used of a brahmin at DN 4:8.17.

sn7.15:1.3.pli: So neva mātaraṃ abhivādeti, na pitaraṃ abhivādeti, na ācariyaṃ abhivādeti, na jeṭṭhabhātaraṃ abhivādeti.
sn7.15:1.3.eng: He didn’t bow to his mother or father, his tutor, or his oldest brother.

sn7.15:1.4.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā mahatiyā parisāya parivuto dhammaṃ deseti.
sn7.15:1.4.eng: Now, at that time the Buddha was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

sn7.15:1.6.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo mahatiyā parisāya parivuto dhammaṃ deseti.
sn7.15:1.6.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

sn7.15:1.8.pli: Sace maṃ samaṇo gotamo ālapissati, ahampi taṃ ālapissāmi.
sn7.15:1.8.eng: If he speaks to me, I’ll speak to him.

sn7.15:1.9.pli: No ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo ālapissati, ahampi nālapissāmī”ti.
sn7.15:1.9.eng: But if he doesn’t speak, neither will I.”

sn7.15:1.10.pli: Atha kho mānatthaddho brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tuṇhībhūto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn7.15:1.10.eng: Then the brahmin Stuck-Up went up to the Buddha, and stood silently to one side.

sn7.15:1.11.eng: But the Buddha didn’t speak to him.

sn7.15:1.13.pli: “nāyaṃ samaṇo gotamo kiñci jānātī”ti tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
sn7.15:1.13.eng: “This ascetic Gotama knows nothing!” And he wanted to go back from there right away.

sn7.15:1.14.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mānatthaddhassa brāhmaṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya mānatthaddhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.15:1.14.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing Stuck-Up’s train of thought, addressed him in verse:

sn7.15:2.2.eng: if you want what’s good for you, brahmin.

sn7.15:3.2.pli: “cittaṃ me samaṇo gotamo jānātī”ti tattheva bhagavato pādesu sirasā nipatitvā bhagavato pādāni mukhena ca paricumbati pāṇīhi ca parisambāhati, nāmañca sāveti:
sn7.15:3.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama knows my mind!” He bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:

sn7.15:3.3.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I am Stuck-Up! I am Stuck-Up!”

sn7.15:3.4.pli: Atha kho sā parisā abbhutavittajātā ahosi:

sn7.15:3.6.pli: Ayañhi mānatthaddho brāhmaṇo neva mātaraṃ abhivādeti, na pitaraṃ abhivādeti, na ācariyaṃ abhivādeti, na jeṭṭhabhātaraṃ abhivādeti;
sn7.15:3.6.eng: This brahmin Stuck-Up doesn’t bow to his mother or father, his tutor, or his oldest brother.

sn7.15:3.7.pli: atha ca pana samaṇe gotame evarūpaṃ paramanipaccakāraṃ karotī”ti.
sn7.15:3.7.eng: Yet he shows such utmost deference to the ascetic Gotama!”

sn7.15:3.8.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mānatthaddhaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.15:3.8.eng: Then the Buddha said to the brahmin Stuck-Up,

sn7.15:3.9.eng: “Enough, brahmin. Get up, and take your own seat.

sn7.15:3.10.eng: For your mind has confidence in me.”

sn7.15:3.11.pli: Atha kho mānatthaddho brāhmaṇo sake āsane nisīditvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.15:3.11.eng: Then Stuck-Up took his seat and said to the Buddha:

sn7.15:4.1.eng: “Regarding whom should you not be conceited?

sn7.15:4.4.eng: Who is it good to venerate properly?”

sn7.15:5.4.eng: Regarding these you should not be conceited.

sn7.15:5.5.eng: They are who you should respect.

sn7.15:5.6.eng: They are who you should esteem.

sn7.15:5.7.eng: And they’re who it’s good to venerate properly.

sn7.15:6.1.eng: And when with bent knee, not stiff with conceit,

sn7.15:6.3.comm: Given the context, I think nihacca here has the same sense as it does more explicitly at Thig 5.9:3.1, “bending the knee”.

sn7.15:6.4.eng: their task complete, free of defilements.”

sn7.15:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mānatthaddho brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.15:7.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Stuck-Up said to the Buddha,

sn7.15:7.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.15:7.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.16:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena paccanīkasāto nāma brāhmaṇo sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati.
sn7.16:1.2.eng: Now at that time a brahmin named Contraphile, who loved contradiction, was residing in Sāvatthī.
sn7.16:1.2.comm: Paccanīkasāta, “Pleased by contradiction”. Even though the construction “named” is used, it is clearly an epithet rather than a proper name.

sn7.16:1.4.eng: “Why don’t I go to the ascetic Gotama and

sn7.16:1.5.pli: Yaṃ yadeva samaṇo gotamo bhāsissati taṃ tadevassāhaṃ paccanīkāssan”ti.

sn7.16:1.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā abbhokāse caṅkamati.
sn7.16:1.6.eng: At that time the Buddha was walking mindfully in the open air.

sn7.16:1.7.pli: Atha kho paccanīkasāto brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ caṅkamantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.16:1.7.eng: Then the brahmin Contraphile went up to the Buddha, and said to him as he was walking,

sn7.16:3.3.eng: and you’ve got rid of resentment,

sn7.16:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, paccanīkasāto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.16:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Contraphile said to the Buddha,

sn7.16:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.16:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.17:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn7.17:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn7.17:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe kammantaṃ kārāpeti.
sn7.17:1.2.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Builder was having some building work done in that jungle thicket.
sn7.17:1.2.comm: Navakammika, “builder”. The causative form is used, kārāpeti. He was not a manual laborer, but someone who supervised others to get the work done.

sn7.17:1.3.pli: Addasā kho navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ aññatarasmiṃ sālarukkhamūle nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn7.17:1.3.eng: He saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged at the root of a certain sal tree, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.

sn7.17:1.4.eng: Seeing this, it occurred to him,

sn7.17:1.5.pli: “ahaṃ kho imasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe kammantaṃ kārāpento ramāmi.
sn7.17:1.5.eng: “I enjoy having this building work done here in the jungle.

sn7.17:1.6.pli: Ayaṃ samaṇo gotamo kiṃ kārāpento ramatī”ti?
sn7.17:1.6.eng: I wonder what the ascetic Gotama enjoys having done?”

sn7.17:1.7.pli: Atha kho navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.17:1.7.eng: Then Bhāradvāja the Builder went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn7.17:2.1.eng: “What kind of works are done by you,

sn7.17:2.2.eng: a mendicant in the sal jungle?

sn7.17:3.1.eng: “There’s nothing I need do in the jungle;

sn7.17:3.2.eng: my jungle’s cut at the root, it’s withered away.
sn7.17:3.2.comm: Accept the reading visukkha, which is supported by SA2 96, 一切盡枯.

sn7.17:3.3.eng: Free of snarls and thorns in the jungle,
sn7.17:3.3.comm: This verse plays on vana (“jungle”) and vanatha, explained by the commentary as “undergrowth”, and applied in the sense of the tangles and “snarls” of craving.

sn7.17:3.4.eng: I enjoy solitude, having given up discontent.”

sn7.17:4.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.17:4.1.eng: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Builder said to the Buddha,

sn7.17:4.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.17:4.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.18:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati aññatarasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe.
sn7.18:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kosalans in a certain forest grove.

sn7.18:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa bhāradvājagottassa brāhmaṇassa sambahulā antevāsikā kaṭṭhahārakā māṇavakā yena vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā addasaṃsu bhagavantaṃ tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā. Disvāna yena bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhāradvājagottaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn7.18:1.2.eng: Then several students, pupils of one of the Bhāradvāja brahmins, approached a forest grove while collecting firewood. They saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged at the root of a certain sal tree, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence. Seeing this, they went up to Bhāradvāja and said to him,

sn7.18:1.4.pli: Asukasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe samaṇo nisinno pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā”.
sn7.18:1.4.eng: In such and such a forest grove the ascetic Gotama is sitting down cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.”

sn7.18:1.5.pli: Atha kho bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo tehi māṇavakehi saddhiṃ yena so vanasaṇḍo tenupasaṅkami.
sn7.18:1.5.eng: Then Bhāradvāja together with those young students went to that forest grove

sn7.18:1.6.pli: Addasā kho bhagavantaṃ tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
sn7.18:1.6.eng: where he saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.

sn7.18:1.7.pli: Disvāna yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn7.18:1.7.eng: He went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn7.18:2.1.eng: “Deep in the jungle so full of terrors,

sn7.18:2.2.eng: you’ve plunged into the empty, desolate wilderness.

sn7.18:3.1.pli: Na yattha gītaṃ napi yattha vāditaṃ,
sn7.18:3.1.eng: Where there is no song or music,

sn7.18:3.2.eng: a lonely sage resorts to the wilderness.

sn7.18:3.3.eng: This strikes me as an amazing thing,

sn7.18:3.4.eng: that you dwell so joyfully alone in the jungle.

sn7.18:4.1.eng: I suppose you wish to be reborn in the company

sn7.18:4.2.eng: of the supreme world-sovereign of the Third Heaven.
sn7.18:4.2.comm: The brahmin takes tidiva as the Brahmā realm rather than that of Indra (see note on SN 3.21:15.5).

sn7.18:4.3.eng: Is that why you resort to the desolate wilderness,

sn7.18:4.4.eng: to practice fervor for attaining divinity?”

sn7.18:5.1.eng: “Any wishes and hopes that are always attached

sn7.18:5.2.eng: to the many and various realms—
sn7.18:5.2.comm: Here dhātu means loka (“realm”), not “element”.

sn7.18:5.3.eng: the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—

sn7.18:5.4.eng: I’ve eliminated them all down to the root.
sn7.18:5.4.comm: The Buddha rejects the brahmin’s supposition (see MN 26:15.35 and note).

sn7.18:6.2.eng: amongst all things, my vision is clear.

sn7.18:6.3.eng: I’ve attained the state of grace, <j>the supreme awakening;

sn7.18:6.4.eng: I meditate alone, brahmin, and self-assured.”

sn7.18:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhāradvājagotto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.18:7.1.eng: When he had spoken, Bhāradvāja said to the Buddha,

sn7.18:7.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn7.19:0.3.eng: The Brahmin Who Provided for His Mother

sn7.19:1.2.pli: Atha kho mātuposako brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn7.19:1.2.eng: Then a brahmin who provided for his mother went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn7.19:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mātuposako brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.19:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

sn7.19:1.4.pli: “ahañhi, bho gotama, dhammena bhikkhaṃ pariyesāmi, dhammena bhikkhaṃ pariyesitvā mātāpitaro posemi.
sn7.19:1.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I seek alms by legitimate means, which I use to provide for my mother and father.
sn7.19:1.4.comm: “Alms” is bhikkhā, which is anything procured through begging.

sn7.19:1.5.pli: Kaccāhaṃ, bho gotama, evaṅkārī kiccakārī homī”ti?
sn7.19:1.5.eng: In doing so, am I doing my duty?”

sn7.19:1.6.eng: “Indeed, brahmin, in so doing you are doing your duty.

sn7.19:1.7.pli: Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, dhammena bhikkhaṃ pariyesati, dhammena bhikkhaṃ pariyesitvā mātāpitaro poseti, bahuṃ so puññaṃ pasavatīti.
sn7.19:1.7.eng: Whoever seeks alms by legitimate means, and uses them to provide for their mother and father brims with much merit.

sn7.19:2.1.eng: A mortal provides for their mother

sn7.19:2.5.eng: they’re praised in this life by the astute,

sn7.19:2.6.eng: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

sn7.19:3.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mātuposako brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn7.19:3.1.eng: When he said this, the brahmin who provided for his mother said to the Buddha,

sn7.19:3.3.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn7.19:3.3.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
